parts.label: (i)

content.text: Place the metre ruler on the bench with its scale facing upwards. Arrange one of the wooden blocks and the five marbles as shown in Fig. 1.1
Measure the length \(D\) for the five marbles
Using your value of \(D\), calculate the average diameter \(d_{1}\) of **one** marble

issues: LaTeX subscript (_) found outside math mode
LaTeX subscript (_) found outside math mode

content.text: Suggest why it is more accurate, when using a ruler, to measure \(D\) for **five** marbles rather than measure the diameter of a single marble
Describe how the two wooden blocks and one of the marbles can be used to determine an accurate value for the diameter of a marble
Draw a diagram to show your suggested arrangement
Describe clearly how you ensure that your value for the diameter of a marble is as accurate as possible
Use your arrangement to measure the diameter \(d_{2}\) of the marble
Use the top-pan balance as shown in Fig. 1.2 to measure the mass \(m\) of one of the marbles

parts.label: (ii)

content.text: Pour approximately \(25 \text{cm}^3\) of water into the measuring cylinder
Record the reading \(V_{1}\) of the water level in the measuring cylinder

issues: LaTeX subscript (_) found outside math mode

content.text: Carefully place the 5 marbles into the water in the measuring cylinder as shown in Fig. 1.3
Record the new reading \(V_{2}\) of the water level in the measuring cylinder

content.text: Calculate a value for the average volume \(V\) of **one** marble. Use the equation

content.text: Draw, on Fig. 1.3, an arrow showing the correct line of sight for reading the water level in the measuring cylinder
Calculate a value for the density \(\rho\) of the material from which the marble is made. Use your values of \(m\) from (c)(i), \(V\) from (c)(ii) and the equation
Describe one possible source of inaccuracy in the method described in (c) and suggest one improvement to reduce its effect
source of inaccuracy
improvement
In this experiment, you will determine the diameter of a marble by two methods and calculate the density of the material from which the marble is made
Carry out the following instructions, referring to Fig. 1.1
Experiment A
Pour \(100 \text{cm}^3\) of hot water into the beaker
Place the thermometer in the water in the beaker
In the first row of Table 2.1, record the temperature \(\theta_{\mathrm{A}}\) of the water at time \(t = 0 \text{s}\) and immediately start the stop-watch

Record, in Table 2.1, the temperature \(\theta_{\mathrm{A}}\) of the water at times \(t = 30 \text{s}\), \(t = 60 \text{s}\), \(t = 90 \text{s}\), \(t = 120 \text{s}\), \(t = 150 \text{s}\) and \(t = 180 \text{s}\).
Empty the beaker
Experiment B
Pour \(100 \text{cm}^3\) of hot water into the beaker
Place the thermometer in the water in the beaker
Wait until the temperature \(\theta_{\mathrm{B}}\) of the water has reached the same value as the temperature \(\theta_{\mathrm{A}}\) at \(t = 90 \text{s}\) in Experiment A
In the first row of Table 2.1, record this temperature \(\theta_{\mathrm{B}}\) of the water at time \(t = 0 \text{s}\) and immediately start the stop-watch
Write a conclusion stating how the temperature at \(t = 0s\) affects the rate of cooling of the water
Justify your answer by reference to values from your results
Calculate the average cooling rate \(x_{1}\) during the second half of Experiment A
Use your readings from Table 2.1 and the equation
where \(T = 90 \mathrm{~s}\) and \(\theta_{\mathrm{A}90}\) and \(\theta_{\mathrm{A}180}\) are the temperatures at \(t = 90 \mathrm{~s}\) and \(t = 180 \mathrm{~s}\) in Experiment A
Include the unit for the cooling rate
Calculate the average cooling rate \(x_{2}\) during the first half of Experiment B
Use the readings from Table 2.1 and the equation
where \(T = 90 \mathrm{~s}\) and \(\theta_{\mathrm{B}0}\) and \(\theta_{\mathrm{B}90}\) are the temperatures at \(t = 0 \mathrm{~s}\) and \(t = 90 \mathrm{~s}\) in Experiment B
A student suggests that \(x_{1}\) and \(x_{2}\) should be the same
State whether your results support this suggestion
Justify your statement by reference to your results
statement
justification
State one variable which must be controlled so that the comparison of \(x_{1}\) and \(x_{2}\) is valid
In this experiment, you will investigate the cooling of hot water from different initial temperatures
Carry out the following instructions, referring to Fig. 2.1
Connect the crocodile clip to a length \(l = 20.0 \text{cm}\) of the resistance wire
Close the switch
Measure and record in Table 3.1, the value of potential difference (p.d.) \(V\) and current \(I\) for the resistance wire
Connect the crocodile clip to lengths \(l = 40.0 \text{cm}\) , \(l = 60.0 \text{cm}\) , \(l = 80.0 \text{cm}\) and \(l = 100.0 \text{cm}\) of the resistance wire
For each length \(l,\) measure and record in Table 3.1, the value of potential difference \(V\) and current \(I\) for the resistance wire
Open the switch
For each length \(l\) calculate and record in Table 3.1, the resistance \(R\) of the resistance wire. Use your values of \(V\) and \(I\) from Table 3.1 and the equation
Plot a graph of \(R / \Omega\) (y-axis) against \(l / \text{cm}\) (x-axis)
Draw a straight line of best fit
Determine the gradient \(G\) of the graph. Show clearly on the graph how you obtained the necessary information
The gradient \(G\) is numerically equal to the resistance per unit length \(R_0\) of the resistance wire
Write down the value of \(R_0\) for the resistance wire
Suggest one practical reason why students carrying out this experiment may not obtain the same readings as yours. Assume that the procedure has been done carefully
In this experiment, you will determine the resistance per unit length of a resistance wire. The circuit has been set up for you
Carry out the following instructions, referring to Fig. 3.1
A student investigates the motion of a ball through the air
Plan an experiment which will enable him to investigate how the range of the ball depends on the angle at which it is launched
The range is the horizontal distance that the ball travels after leaving the end of the channel shown in Fig. 4.1 and before hitting the ground
You are **not** required to do the experiment
The apparatus available includes:
a flexible channel, as shown in Fig. 4.1, which can be bent at different angles
a selection of balls, each of different diameter and mass
In your plan, you should:
list any additional apparatus needed
explain briefly how to do the experiment  you may add to Fig. 4.1 if it helps your explanation
state the key variables to keep constant
draw a table with column headings, to show how to display the readings (you are **not** required to enter any readings in the table)
explain how to use the results to reach a conclusion
